case_vignette: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination one week after a chest x-ray showed a solitary pulmonary nodule. He has no history of major medical illness. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A tuberculin skin test is negative. A CT scan of the chest shows a 2.1-cm well-circumscribed, calcified nodule in the periphery of the right lower lung field. A CT-guided biopsy of the lesion is performed. Histological examination of the biopsy specimen shows regions of disorganized hyaline cartilage interspersed with myxoid regions and clefts of ciliated epithelium.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm actually feeling pretty normal and don't have any symptoms to report.
Have you had any recent blood tests or health screenings with abnormal results?
About a week ago, a chest x-ray showed a spot on my lung, but I haven't been feeling sick or anything.
How old are you and what is your sex?
I am a 56-year-old man.
Do you have a history of smoking or exposure to substances that could affect the lungs?
Yes, I've smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years.
Have you lost weight recently without trying?
No, I haven't lost any weight recently.
Have you had any previous cancers or a family history of cancer?
I have no history of major medical illnesses, which includes having no history of cancer.
Do you have a shortness of breath, coughing, or coughing up blood?
No, I haven't experienced any of those symptoms.

Given the history of long-term smoking and a spot on the lung found on an x-ray, even in the absence of symptoms, it's important to rule out lung cancer.

Final Diagnosis: Possible lung cancer, recommend further diagnostic evaluation with CT scan and referral to a pulmonologist or oncologist.
